painpoints: ['Lack of innovation process understanding', "Resistance to fast-tracking processes, 'it is what it is' attitude", 'Difficulty pushing projects during holidays/low appetite', 'Frustration among keen individuals', 'Inefficient communication with UWs (brokers)', 'Time-constrained quoting/placing (brokers)', 'Lack of transparent product comparison (brokers)', 'Ignored submissions (brokers)', 'Unclear project status (brokers)', 'Slow sign-off process (brokers)', 'Many MVPs, few scale ideas in corporate innovation']
desired_solutions: ['Improved innovation process understanding and goals', 'Faster process execution and project progression', 'Overcoming organisational inertia', 'Better communication with UWs', 'More efficient quoting and placing business', 'Transparent product comparison tools', 'Clearer project status and sign-off', 'Scalable innovation outcomes', 'Deployment of Lab-in-a-Box', 'Improved governance and operating model', 'Unblocking innovation barriers', 'Clear innovation roadmap', 'Expanded innovation training (additional/wider audience)', 'Progressing ideas from backlog', 'Advancing current ideas to later stages (Stage 3, Phase 2)']
ninety_summary: ['Innovates for global insurance sector, improving innovation capabilities.', 'Specialist practitioners taking new insurance ideas to market in 60 days.', 'Builds innovation capabilities, labs, and learning for insurers.', 'Expertise in the 123 Framework™ (Design Thinking, Lean Startup, Agile) and Innovation ABC accelerants.', 'Offers Insurance Innovation Maturity Audit, Training Modules, Lab-in-a-Box™.', 'Mission: Help insurers innovate and thrive; Vision: Innovation as norm, extreme poverty as exception.', 'Focuses on accelerating delivery, effective ideation, and disruptive strategies/cultures.', "Emphasizes decision gates to 'fail fast' and planning for scale."]
other_information: ['Client: Talbot (Phase 1 Sponsor Wrap Up project).', 'Ninety locations: London, New York.', 'Talbot Achievements: Generated 15 ideas (Cyber, PV, existing/new customers/products), completed topic lead activities, identified assumptions/ran experiments (financial case, wireframe), identified customer problems via 6 broker interviews/10 surveys.', 'Talbot Learnings: How to talk to customers, how ideation/stages 1-2 run (will author playbook), roles/responsibilities template.', 'Talbot Organisational Engagement: 261 total participants (ideations, stages, training, maturity audit, 1:1s).', 'Proposed 2019 Roadmap for client: Includes online distribution, alternative risk portfolio, Lab-in-a-Box deployment, idea challenges, innovation platform implementation, and multiple product pilots.', 'Current Phase Next Steps: Ninety to finalize deliverables, Talbot to decide on next execution steps and Ninety engagement.']

painpoints: Decreasing company longevity due to lack of innovation, unclear understanding of innovation, neglect of strategic innovation, ideas lack evidence for investment, inconsistent innovation approach, ineffective customer understanding, solving wrong problems, lack of curiosity, poorly defined problem statements, limited creativity, absence of psychological safety, group ideation issues (production blocking, evaluation apprehension).
desired_solutions: Customer-centric design thinking for products, structured innovation methodology (123 framework), rapid experimentation and validation, building evidence for investable ideas, consistent and accountable innovation, effective customer engagement tools, focusing on problems before solutions, cultivating curiosity and diverse thinking, crafting clear customer-focused problem statements, creating psychological safety for idea generation.
ninety_summary: Ninety is an award-winning consultancy that helps the global insurance sector innovate and improve its innovation capabilities. They make innovation happen through training and a structured 123 framework for bringing new ideas to market, contributing significant profits to charity.
other_information: 90% of Ninety's distributable profits go to charity, supporting the global extreme poor (e.g., $10,000 donation to South Sudan schools). The bootcamp emphasizes setting group mindsets and outcomes. It uses real-world examples like Oral B and Juicero to illustrate customer-centricity.

painpoints: Rapid change in IPMI market due to COVID-19 and changing consumer behavior. Need to diversify business and explore new disruptive products/services for new/existing customer segments. Lack of understanding of global insurance innovation landscape ('art of the possible'). Need to generate innovative 'idea seeds' that deliver growth and align with existing AXA GH capabilities/brand. (Prior engagement) Inefficient lead management in EU office. Emerging segments expect simplicity, digital options, and perceived value beyond claims.
desired_solutions: Diversify business with new, disruptive products/services for new/existing segments. Obtain deep insights into global insurance innovation landscape. Develop innovative product/service ideas ('idea seeds') that align with AXA GH's strategy and capabilities. (Prior engagement) Improve lead management efficiency and create new insurance solutions for emerging segments. Create a combined value proposition: digital platform, simplified product, subscription pricing, value-added services.
ninety_summary: Award-winning innovation experts for global insurance, offering training, op model best practices, market context (Navigator), and innovation delivery (123 Framework). Proposed 10-12 week engagement for AXA GH to provide market insights, generate disruptive ideas, and create an innovation roadmap, for £88.5k. Previously helped AXA GH (or related AXA entity) with customer interception, problem validation, and developing new value propositions for emerging segments. 90% distributable profits go to charity.
other_information: Document date: September 2021. Client: AXA Global Healthcare (AXA GH), leading IPMI provider. Prior engagement (April 2021, starting late 2020) with AXA (or related entity) focused on lead management and innovation for new global health insurance segments, resulted in a new proposition. Engagement requirements: project sponsor, access to strategy/stakeholders, remote interaction. Team: Dan White, Nick Reed, Ewa Clibborn-Dyer.

painpoints: {'Claire': "Struggles to prioritize risks, understand protection after an incident, find products reflecting her context, understand risks of possessions, lacks control over protections, feels 'one-size-fits-all'.", 'Murray': 'Cannot protect family/self in one process, too much admin for travel insurance, cannot alter insurance to accommodate changing needs, struggles to choose best products, manages family risks separately.', 'Larry': 'Finds it hard to understand/compare options, cannot alter insurance for changing needs, struggles to decide best options, has to deal with multiple insurers, feels insurer relationship is transactional/time-consuming/adds little value.'}
desired_solutions: {'Under my AXA’rella (Larry)': "A 'one stop shop' platform to access/manage all insurance covers ('modules') in one place, providing control and clarity.", 'Just for you (Murray)': 'Personalized product/service recommendations based on daily activities, ensuring customers see only relevant options.', 'Your Choice (Claire)': 'A single, flexible insurance product with one renewal date, allowing customers to choose modules, start/length/payment methods, and transfer existing policies.', 'MyFamily (Murray)': 'A shared family platform allowing policyholders to grant access levels, making all family members responsible for their policies.', 'AXA Lens (Claire)': 'An app allowing users to photograph possessions, identify objects/risks, and choose coverage for specific risks with security.', 'Aunt AXA (Larry)': 'A trusted advisor platform offering advice on insurance matters, highlighting protection gaps, and providing discounts/offers to loyal customers.'}
ninety_summary: AXA Ireland is undertaking a structured, customer-centric innovation project ("Reimagining retail insurance") to define its 2028 customer experience. This initiative focuses on identifying distinct customer personas (Claire, Murray, Larry) and their pain points, then co-creating solutions. The process has yielded 6 customer-prioritized ideas centered on modular 'singular products', AXA as a 'trusted advisor', and delivering clear value. Key strategic gaps have been identified for future exploration, including claims, embedded insurance, non-insurance offerings, and partnerships. The project is now moving into a testing sprint for proposition validation.
other_information: {'Project Sponsor': 'AXA Ireland', 'Project Goal': 'To articulate how customers see, understand & interact with AXA’s retail insurance in 2028.', 'Methodology': 'Multi-part innovation approach involving workshops, customer problem canvases, idea generation/prioritization with customer validation, and internal team engagement.', 'Customer Personas': 'Claire (Risk Taker), Murray (Deferred Buyer), Larry (Family First).', 'Key Themes from Solutions': "Customers want a singular product (with modular coverage), AXA as a 'trusted advisor', and services with clear purpose/value.", 'Foundation Stones for Solutions': 'Regular/purpose-driven communications, data leveraged for reduced customer effort, competitive price point.', 'Identified Gaps to Address': 'Focus on claims, exploration of embedded insurance, non-insurance offerings, and partnerships (the latter out of scope for this analysis).', 'Next Steps': 'Start testing sprint, analyze results, build narrative for winning propositions.'}

painpoints: Global plastic pollution and associated financial costs; lack of adequate insurance solutions for plastic impact. Ageing population challenges: financial insecurity, digital exclusion, isolation, poor health, disability; current insurance approaches are reactive (premium adjustments), not innovative. Gender inequality: pay gaps, economic disparity, lack of representation, safety concerns (abuse, assault); insurance industry largely neglects these risks. Within the insurance industry: innovation disillusionment, lack of incentives, structures, and training, leading to missed opportunities and cultural stagnation.
desired_solutions: Solve plastic pollution by creating new markets and streamlining expenditure, insuring impact rather than producers. Innovate for ageing populations: create new markets, address lifestyle needs (work, care), explore new insurance products (memory, relationships). Address gender inequality: create new markets by serving women's specific needs in insurance. For the insurance industry: empower employees through innovation training, change culture to foster proactive innovation, develop innovation communities and practitioners, and deliver tangible solutions via structured innovation frameworks.
ninety_summary: Ninety catalyzes innovation in risk & insurance, incubating bold ideas, upskilling teams, and creating innovation structures. 90% of distributable profits go to charity. They offer the 'Innovation Gym Suite' with HIIT (digital innovation program), Bootcamp (intensive 123 Framework training), and PT (Facilitation Masterclass) to develop innovation skills, mindsets, and cultures. They use an award-winning 123 Framework for rapid idea development and market launch. Case studies include helping Aviva build an innovation culture, Zurich upskill leadership, and Generali develop innovation champions.
other_information: The text identifies three strategic rationales for joint ventures: Plastic as a Risk, Impact of an Ageing Population, and Gender Inequality & Women's Safety. Each is described as a 'big and growing problem,' 'hot space' attracting money, and a 'meaningful financial opportunity' that is an 'underserved space in insurance & risk management.' Key statistics include: $3.7tn lifetime cost of plastic production annually, older UK consumers spending £550bn annually by 2040, and a 15% gender pay gap in the UK (30% in financial services). Ninety is 'Consultancy of the Year 2019, 2020 & 2021' and uses a '123 Framework for new insurance ideas to market in 60 days.'

painpoints: Manual tracking of account objectives and actions; lack of centralized visibility on client intelligence, financials, relationship mapping, and opportunities; inconsistent tracking of competition and whitespace; difficulty in consistent client understanding and strategic relationship building; manual data aggregation for market trends and financial analysis.
desired_solutions: A centralized platform for account planning, objective setting, and action tracking; automated visibility on historic and forecasted spend, opportunities, and client financials; structured tools for relationship mapping (org charts, matrix, heat map) and strategy; integration with CRM; systematic identification and tracking of opportunities (secured, unsecured, lost, no bid); consistent framework for client intelligence and market trend analysis.
ninety_summary: Ninety provides a structured and centralized platform for comprehensive account planning and management. It automates tracking of client objectives, actions, financials, and opportunities, enhancing visibility and consistency. Ninety enables detailed relationship mapping and strategic development to strengthen client engagement and identify growth opportunities.
other_information: The text is a detailed internal template for client account planning, covering various aspects from objectives and client intelligence to financial performance, market analysis, relationship mapping, and opportunity tracking. It aims to guide account teams in understanding clients, identifying opportunities, and managing relationships strategically.

painpoints: Cannot see beyond tier 1 suppliers; lack of overall supply chain visibility; inability to benchmark supply chain performance; no alerts for potential disruptions.
desired_solutions: Web-based service for supply chain transparency (beyond tier 1), real-time disruption alerts, and KPI-based benchmarking for identifying weak areas.
ninety_summary: Ninety is leading a Mid-Point Review for the AGCS/XSEBI Concept Stage 2, focusing on a supply chain risk solution. They are actively running experiments (surveys, interviews, research) to validate assumptions around customer data, benchmarking, risk valuation, broker relations, buyer personas, and Palantir's use. Most experiments are in initial or ongoing phases.
other_information: Project: AGCS / XSEBI Concept Stage 2, as of Nov 19, 2019. It aims to develop a supply chain risk management solution targeting multinational manufacturers/logistics companies. The business model includes subscription revenue, various data sources (Actuarial, NatCat), and considers Palantir for the pilot. Multiple critical assumptions regarding market acceptance, data availability, and pricing are being tested.

geography: Global (Headquarters: Zurich, Switzerland; operations in North America, Europe, Asia, Australia, Bermuda)
sector: Property, Casualty, and Specialty Insurance and Reinsurance
painpoints: ['Human error in documents', 'Unnecessary length and complexity of documents', 'Confirmations via email rather than formal documents', 'Difficulty tracking and reviewing multiple documents', 'Unclear document format and font', 'Brokers need to explain insurer/brand to clients', 'Unclear policy wording', 'Time-consuming cross-referencing for accuracy', 'Translating complex policy language for clients', 'Multiple document exchanges for quote/bind process', 'Risk of attaching wrong wording leading to coverage issues']

ninety_summary: ['Ninety leads client feedback in the project', 'Facilitates workshops for ideation, vision definition, prioritisation, and pilot planning', "Guides the team through 'smelting' ideas, 'designing the jewellery' (refining vision), and creating visual prototypes/digital mock-ups"]
other_information: ['Project phases include Lead Time, Ideation, Defining the vision, Prioritisation, Requirements, and Pilot planning', 'Workshops are a key activity for ideation, prioritisation, and pilot planning, using Miro', 'Workshop rules emphasize productive conflict, user focus, big-picture thinking, and process trust', "The Jobs to be Done (JTBD) framework is used to understand broker needs (e.g., 'Be confident info is correct', 'Make end-insured understand policy', 'Allow info sharing for quote & bind')", 'Feedback is collected from clients (Ninety-led), brokers (AW UWs-led), and internal stakeholders (Darren-led)', 'A digital mock-up is central to the vision and iterated with feedback']

painpoints: Innovation team is a bottleneck; poor connection between investor and BU priorities (short vs. long-term goals); low cultural readiness for venture optionality; lack of BU pain point visibility for innovation teams; engagement failures due to BU unawareness; 'pushy scout syndrome'.
desired_solutions: Align ventures with Generali strategic priorities, creating measurable impact; create 'receivers' and 'Venture Champions' across Generali; make every investment deployable, make 'Mega Deals' the norm; foster venture-ready culture; outcomes-first approach with quarter-by-quarter measurement; facilitate open innovation; leverage existing workflows; establish Value Creation Plans and Venture Guides for BUs; implement a strategic value dashboard for Group Innovation; operate 'inside-out, not outside-in'; penetrate the whole organization; firewall strategic activities from financial decision-making.
ninety_summary: Ninety operates the Generali Ventures Strategic Transfer Coordination Team, led by Dan White. Ninety's Innovation Champions program will be blended into the Generali program. Ninety subsidizes the program via ARK funding and provides expertise in innovation healthchecks, taking ideas to market, and building innovation capability.
other_information: Project: Ensuring Strategic Transfer AFV - Generali, March 2025. Four core programs: Venture Everywhere, For Everyone; DeepValue; Inspire & Connect; Success. '3 Dans' collaboration: Dan Reed (AFV), Dan White (Ninety), Danilo Raponi (Generali). Program timeline: 3-year main investment period, parallel with Generali's 3-year strategic plan (LP27). Program costed within AFV's market rate economics, subsidized by AFV and Ninety. Financials: Dan White's FOC status subject to ARK funding; approx. 388k EUR for time, approx. 270k EUR for expenses. Key tools: Venture Champion program, Generali Ventures Sandbox, Generali Ventures Intelligence Platform, Generali Ventures Innovation Co-pilot.

painpoints: Lack of innovation technique/training; internal positioning struggles for 'Innovate' team; fear of being outpaced by competitors; specific product ideas with market uncertainty or lack of capacity to explore.
desired_solutions: Build innovation capability ('muscle'); explore and validate new product ideas; improve innovation techniques and training; enhance internal positioning of innovation function; keep pace with or surpass competitors.
ninety_summary: Ninety specializes in helping the global insurance sector build innovation capability and take new insurance ideas to market in 60 days. They offer a battle-tested methodology (123 Framework), training programs (Bootcamp, masterclasses), and tools (Maturity Audit, Lab-in-a-Box).
other_information: Client is Atrium. Two engagement types presented: a specific 'Sharia-compliant product' engagement (approx. £45k + £35k) and a broader 'Innovation programme' (approx. £80k/quarter retained). Key contacts are Justin Emrich (sponsor) and Simon Lewis (product owner). Work to be done on-site at Lloyd's and Ninety's offices.

painpoints: Aviva's customers need support to be more climate-conscious; Uncertainty about key risks/watch-outs; Potential increased time/cost for customer recruitment/scheduling; Time zone challenges for participants; Need to clarify expert engagement strategy.
desired_solutions: Develop new insurance propositions within 60 days to help customers transition to sustainable lives; The 'Gym' program to foster innovation through research, ideation, 8-week collaboration, and pitching; Recruit customers and experts for feedback; Establish clear roles and commitments for all participants.
ninety_summary: Ninety innovates for the global insurance sector, helping it improve innovation. Offers high-intensity innovation training and programs like 'The Gym' product sprint, utilizing Design Thinking and Lean Startup. Provides innovation coaches, project leads, and client partners. Emphasizes mindsets like Curiosity, Creativity, Customer-centricity, Experimental, and Fail fast. Consultancies of the Year 2019, 2020, 2021 with offices in London, New York, Zurich.
other_information: Project: Aviva’s Climate Challenge. Key personnel: Tom Hardcastle (Senior Partner), Emily Gardner (Training Specialist), Eva Forné González (Innovation Consultant), Ewa Clibborn-Dyer (Innovation & Product Manager). Program duration: 8 weeks. Timeline: Mid-October to March. Participants: 12 booked + 4 internal. Customers: 6-8 to be recruited for feedback (cost ~£1,146). Webinar Wc/17th Jan, Ideation Workshop Wc/24th Jan, Kick-off Wc/31st Jan, Final Pitch Wc/28th Mar. Experts: Aviva employees, pitch ideas to them x3.

painpoints: Car buying is time consuming and confusing. Lack of trust in dealers, transparency issues, overwhelming admin process, awkward negotiation. Customers cross-check comparison websites. Skepticism about how services communicate.
desired_solutions: Personalized car recommendations based on lifestyle/needs, total cost of ownership transparency, comprehensive admin management. Single, trusted, unbiased source for car deals. Time-saving, online process with easy test drives, clear financial explanations, post-purchase reminders, and comparison updates. Budget calculator and clear communication.
ninety_summary: Ninety Consulting hosted an MVP Workshop (Jan 2020) for CTM and AutoTrader to generate a personalized car ownership proposition. They facilitated customer interviews, product design, business model canvas, and UX development. Ninety reported a small increase in confidence post-workshop but noted a discrepancy with participant feedback, proposing a 'Stage 2' for further experiments on desirability, feasibility, and viability.
other_information: Clients: CTM (Mortgages) and AutoTrader. Focus: Personalized Car Ownership proposition. Workshop participants included client teams, customers, and Ninety consultants. Contact: Dan White. Included customer interview insights from Chrissie, Lisa, and Ben. Acknowledged an Allianz-PetPlan case study.

painpoints: Skepticism and fatigue towards innovation; perceived as vague. Lack of clear innovation strategy, definition, leader, and governance. Local teams lack confidence, capability, and shared language/process. Inefficient project management due to part-time roles. Insufficient skills, tools, and opportunities for effective innovation. Unclear capital process and no strategic investment approach. Fear of change and failure; lack of collaboration. Innovation not incentivized or recognized. Heavy governance hindering execution. Innovation often top-down and inconsistent. Middle management needs convincing.
desired_solutions: Implement a comprehensive innovation training plan (role-specific tracks, live project application). Establish a hub-and-spoke model with clear methodology and common language. Develop a BMI-branded innovation playbook and toolkit tailored to business/region. Create an accessible, multi-tiered funding mechanism. Launch an innovation champions program and 'train the trainer'. Define clear accountability, KPIs, and light governance. Implement strategic checkpoints for an idea portfolio. Incentivize innovation and recognize efforts. Foster top-level ownership and normalize innovation practices.
ninety_summary: Ninety identified BMI's complex relationship with innovation, marked by skepticism and a lack of clear strategy. Execution is hindered by skill gaps, fear of failure, and unclear processes. Ninety proposes a comprehensive innovation training plan, a tailored hub-and-spoke model, a BMI-branded playbook/toolkit, and a robust governance framework to build capabilities, foster shared understanding, and embed innovation as a measurable, accountable, everyday practice across the organization, addressing maturity gaps and leveraging existing IP with customization for BMI.
other_information: Client is BMI, an insurance company, focusing on an innovation strategy for 2025 and beyond, specifically in Latin America (Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Guatemala, USA). The proposed model is hub-and-spoke. Ninety has conducted an Innovation HealthCheck (19 interviews, 210 surveys) showing BMI below industry benchmarks in 5 of 6 maturity factors. The innovation methodology is a 5-stage process (Discover, Define, Design, Test, Pilot). Ninety is adapting existing IP (e.g., Generali's WeInnovate playbook) for BMI, customizing for business lines, regional realities, and branding. Key target audience for conviction is the 'mass middle tenure group'.

geography: UK, Europe, North America, Latin America, Asia
painpoints: Existing 'growth and innovation champion' group needs rethinking/resetting, lacks commonality/consistency in proposition development, requires skillset refresh and expanded horizons, needs capability in problem definition/idea validation/assessment, and aims for more tangible outcomes with greater pace/focus/rigor.
desired_solutions: Reimagine and reset the 'growth and innovation champion' group into a committed cohort, expand their horizons, provide a skillset refresh, equip them with innovation tools/techniques, develop a consistent approach to new propositions, galvanize an innovation culture/mindset, achieve tangible outcomes quickly, and maximize champion potential.
ninety_summary: Ninety is an innovation expert for the insurance sector, offering virtual Insurance Innovation Bootcamps based on their 123 Framework. This training equips practitioners with tools and mindsets for problem definition, ideation, filtering, and assessing ideas, leveraging Ninety's battle-tested methodology for bringing new insurance ideas to market in 60 days.
other_information: Target: Beazley's 'growth and innovation champion' network (c. 30 members). Bootcamp includes 3 x 4-hour workshops, 1 hour coaching, for up to 10 participants. Format is 100% remote. Fees: £12,000 per bootcamp, £10,000 for 3+, or bundles like £24,000 for 2, £30,000 for 3 (excluding VAT). Timeline: approx. 2 weeks for two training sets. Ninety's framework will be used, referencing Beazley's internal framework.

painpoints: Reduced confidentiality/integrity/availability, reputation damage, financial loss from breaches, non-compliance with regulations (e.g., UK DPA), insufficient security awareness, physical/logical security gaps, need to consolidate learnings, accelerate growth, and deploy best practices in proposition development.
desired_solutions: Robust information security policy, defined responsibilities, risk assessment framework, secure data storage and encryption, access controls, incident response, regular backups, disaster recovery, Ninety's 123 Framework for structured proposition development, collaborative client engagement.
ninety_summary: Ninety maintains a comprehensive Information Security Policy to protect its and client data, ensuring compliance and business continuity. Additionally, Ninety offers its 123 Framework and team expertise to help clients accelerate growth and innovate insurance propositions.
other_information: Information Security Policy dated Feb 12th, 2019, authored by Nkechi Langley. Office locations in London and New York. Client (Allianz AGCS) mentioned in October 2019 presentation. Ninety team members for presentation: Harvey Wade, Tom Hardcastle, Dan Webster, Michael Bean.

painpoints: Incumbents underutilize available digital technology and data. They lack the ambition to digitize and achieve UX excellence compared to new players. Complacency risks being outmaneuvered by 'newcumbents'. Legacy systems and corporate culture impede rapid innovation and greenfield approaches. Difficulty scaling digital-first models to complex products is a concern.
desired_solutions: Incumbents should maximize existing and new digital technologies, squeezing 'lemons' harder. They need to develop strong digital ambition and UX, leveraging historical data with new data capture. Adopting greenfield approaches, hiring entrepreneurial talent, and giving NewCo freedoms are key. Focus on driving bold transformations in distribution, ecosystems, and new mutuals. Learn from 'bigger fish' like Ping An for tech advancements.
ninety_summary: Lemonade's success isn't due to 'magic' tech but smart application. Its growth model is a 'leaky bucket' with modest retention and poor LTV, likely to face headwinds. Lemonade may be a 'MySpace' for insurtech, paving the way for other 'newcumbents'. Ninety advises incumbents to 'Rise to the challenge' by leveraging their inherent strengths (data, brand, LTV) and embracing deeper, more fundamental transformations rather than fearing Lemonade.
other_information: Ninety is an innovation expert for the insurance sector, taking ideas to market in 60 days. They have global offices and donate 90% of distributable profits to charity. Lemonade is framed as a challenge, not a threat. Lemonade's strengths include digital-first UX and AI/ML, but weaknesses include unproven scalability for complex products and limited data quality. The market is shifting from tailwinds to headwinds for Lemonade. Ninety recommends the 'Rise to the challenge' option, specifically for Chubb, citing examples of other incumbents innovating.

sector: Health insurance, pharmacy benefits management, health services
painpoints: ['Decline in past strengths/struggle to maintain innovation.', 'Decreasing corporate longevity; accelerating creative destruction.', 'Over-reliance on old industry expertise is insufficient; new skill sets needed.', 'Industry headwinds: culture, new market entrants, AI, talent war, cost of living, macro changes.', "Significant 'protection gap' and 'Great Risks protection gap' unaddressed by current insurance.", 'Innovation mostly optimizes existing risks, failing to enter new market opportunities.', 'Commercial, culture, market conditions can hinder innovation.', "Traditional project management struggles with innovation's inherent ambiguity/uncertainty.", 'Lack of clear validation steps for innovation success (unlike start-ups).', 'Relying solely on tools/methodologies without the right mindset is insufficient.']
desired_solutions: ['Utilize customer-centric approaches for desirable products.', 'Identify and refine innovation opportunities, solve with idea generation.', 'Apply design thinking lenses (desirability, feasibility, viability) to evaluate ideas.', 'Innovation directly leads to more company value/money.', 'Introduce 10 types of insurance innovation taxonomy.', 'Strategy and clear definition are key; innovation should be inclusive.', "Implement Ninety's 123 framework (Empathise & Define, Ideate & Stretch, Prototype, Test, Scale) for fast idea-to-market.", 'Design thinking emphasizes continuous customer focus, accountable stage gates, and iterative development.', 'Innovation requires blending creativity with discipline and robust governance.', 'Adopt a start-up mindset: validate problem, solution, and growth; leaders sponsor WeInnovate.', 'Define innovation clearly, prioritize execution over just ideas.', 'Cultivate 5 core mindsets: Curiosity, Creativity, Customer-centricity, Experimental, Fail fast.', 'Leaders must foster an environment for innovation by promoting specific mindset behaviors.']
ninety_summary: ['Innovates for global insurance sector, helps it become better at innovation.', 'Consultancy of the Year 2019, 2020, 2021 & 2022.', 'Makes innovation happen.', '90% of distributable profits go to charity; training benefits global extreme poor; recent $10k donation helped 1,452 South Sudan children.', 'Mission: To help insurers innovate and thrive.']
other_information: ['Mindsets for the session: Weekend Self, Time Masters, Digi Mindful.', 'Great Risks protection gap is >$100tn, 25x current global insurance market.', 'Innovation can be categorized into visible (BAU, Core, Exploratory) and invisible types, and various organizational approaches.', 'Taxonomy for innovation includes internal mechanics, core offering, external customer experience.', '123 framework includes 5 stages: Empathise/Define, Ideate/Stretch, Prototype (3 lenses: Desirability, Feasibility, Viability), Test (2-week sprint), Scale.', 'Innovation Archetypes: Newcomer, Everyday innovator, Practitioner, Influencer, Advocate, Sponsor.']

painpoints: Inconsistent idea sourcing and filtering across regions; lack of a standardized, transparent, and fair selection process for innovation initiatives; potential for funding ideas not aligned with strategic principles; challenges in ensuring accountability and clear responsibilities; ineffective communication and feedback mechanisms for applicants; difficulty in objectively assessing and comparing diverse innovation ideas.
desired_solutions: A structured, transparent, and principle-driven innovation funding process; standardized operating, engagement, and governance models for the fund; clear roles and responsibilities for all participants; a multi-stage selection process with objective assessment criteria; effective communication and feedback mechanisms for all stakeholders; tools and templates to standardize idea submission, assessment, and reporting.
ninety_summary: This internal operating guide details the comprehensive framework for the Dai-ichi Life Innovation Fund (DLIF). It outlines principles, operating models, governance, and a multi-stage selection process for innovation initiatives, from local filtering to panel funding decisions. The guide aims to standardize processes, clarify roles, and ensure principle-aligned, transparent funding for transformational ideas across the Dai-ichi Group.
other_information: Client: Dai-ichi Life Group. Fund: Dai-ichi Life Innovation Fund (DLIF). Purpose: Encourage and fund transformational innovation across the group. Key Roles: Core Team, Regional Innovation Teams, Regional Wider Business, DLIF Panel, DLIF Administrators. Processes: Local Filtering, Application, Assessment, Selection Decision, Fund Transfer, Monitoring & Reporting. Assessment Criteria: Eligibility, Suitability (scored out of 12), Disruptiveness (scored out of 45). Timeline: Selection process stages range from 1 day to 2-3 months. Guiding Principles: 13 fund principles. Output: Comprehensive operating guide for an internal innovation fund.

painpoints: Innovation productivity levels seldom mature due to insurers riding an 'innovation rollercoaster,' leading to model failure and 'organ rejection.' This cycle costs $2-10m and removes growth stimulants. Challenges include becoming too platform-focused, disempowering idea owners, acting as an elite 'ivory tower,' failing to communicate, over-committing services, targeting moon-shots too early, becoming a catch-all for all ideas, and orphaned ideas lacking sponsorship. The lab/garage/hub model is often discredited.
desired_solutions: Prevent innovation model failure through better design, building persistent innovation success via an 'Intelligent model Ladder' (12-18 month cycles, less costly). Find the 'right peg for the right hole' using Ninety's architectural framework. Replace IdeaLab with IdeaLab 2.0 as a center for innovation support to generate, capture, and democratize ideas. Develop a fitting operating model, set innovation vision, define capabilities, and plan implementation. Implement disciplined execution, strong decision points, and progress to scale using branding/communications, methodology/tools (e.g., 123 Framework, Innovation Bootcamp), and a program of activities (self-guided digital accelerator, facilitated idea development). Provide ongoing coaching and move to a systemic program of innovation change.
ninety_summary: Ninety is a 'Consultancy of the Year' (2019 & 2020) that innovates for the global insurance sector and helps clients improve their innovation capabilities. They offer an 'Insurance Innovation Blueprint' for predictable and effective innovation, providing an 'architectural framework for Ladder performance' and a toolkit for Chief Innovation Officers. Their offerings include the '123 Framework™' for taking new insurance ideas to market in 60 days, self-guided digital accelerators, and facilitated idea development. They provide unique insurance insights, tools, and accelerants, embedding digital innovation teams with clients to co-create solutions.
other_information: This document is an 'Insurance Innovation Blueprint' introduction for DLG, dated Jan 2021. Research context includes 4,000+ datapoints, 250 companies mapped, 75 surveyed, and 50 senior leaders interviewed. Full (115-page), highlights (70-page), and sample (5-page) reports are available. An internal design note points out a footer typo. Zurich is mentioned as a case study where Ninety delivered an innovation lab, process, and toolset (Zurich Innovation Foundry) within 10 weeks. Ninety has offices in London, New York, and Zurich.

geography: UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, USA
painpoints: Slow market entry for new insurance ideas; High cost of innovation from traditional firms; Lack of internal innovation capability, culture, and structured approach; Difficulty in effective idea vetting and testing; Challenges safely integrating insurtechs and emerging technologies.
desired_solutions: Rapid 60-day market pilot for new insurance ideas; Building internal innovation capabilities, labs, and learning; Structured methodology for innovation (123 Framework, Innovation ABC); Cost-effective, specialized insurance expertise; Co-creation with clients and customers; Flexible risk-reward options including JV and investment.
ninety_summary: Ninety is an insurance-specialist innovation firm that helps global insurers launch new ideas to market in 60 days and build internal innovation capabilities. They utilize proprietary frameworks (123 Framework, Innovation ABC) and co-creation models to deliver accelerated, affordable solutions, often faster and cheaper than Big 4 consultants. Ninety operates as a social enterprise, returning 90% of distributable profits to charity.
other_information: Global presence in London and New York. Leverages a wide range of emerging technologies (e.g., AI, IoT, Blockchain, Chatbots). Boasts a strong blue-chip client list with case studies and testimonials (e.g., Zurich, Allianz). Mission is to help insurers innovate and thrive. Delivers social impact by supporting charitable causes with project profits.

geography: North America, Europe, Bermuda, Asia, International
painpoints: Difficulty identifying and accessing innovation; high failure rate of startups/new ideas (90%) due to lack of market need, cash, team, competition, pricing, or timing; risk of wasting time and budget on poor ideas; challenges in maintaining project momentum and ensuring results; potential workshop engagement issues.
desired_solutions: Uncover meaningful problems, generate customer-centric ideas, establish common innovation mindset and approach, prioritize ideas using defined criteria, assess ideas via Desirability, Feasibility, Viability (DFV) lenses, break down assumptions, design experiments, facilitate Pass/Fail/Pivot decisions to ensure good ideas progress and bad ones are addressed, maintain project momentum, ensure psychological safety, utilize tools like Business Model Canvas and SCAMPER.
ninety_summary: Ninety is an innovation consultancy for the global insurance sector, recognized as 'Consultancy of the Year' multiple times. They deliver comprehensive innovation bootcamps, guiding clients from problem identification to idea testing and project momentum using structured methodologies like BMC, DFV, and Pass/Fail/Pivot. They promote customer-centricity, creative mindsets, efficient resource allocation, and learning from failure.
other_information: Project name: Everest Eggplant. Event: 3-day Insurance Innovation Bootcamp, including separate facilitator training. Trainers: Emily, Saray. Key concepts/tools: SCAMPER, Business Model Canvas (DFV), Dot Voting, Impact/Effort Matrix, Pass/Fail/Pivot framework. Some content includes Spanish terms. Document has inconsistencies in timings and an erroneous end date.

geography: Global (over 30 countries), North America, LATAM, UK&I, EMEA/APAC
painpoints: Need for fail-fast validation, internal blockers to innovation, lack of clear innovation direction/starting point, difficulty gaining executive sponsorship for innovation, potential skills/resource gaps in innovation teams, businesses struggle to manage risk for optimal insurance deals.
desired_solutions: Structured approach for rapid idea validation (fail-fast, experimentation), clear evidence of idea desirability/feasibility/viability, market-ready propositions, scalable innovation, financial and customer benefits, enhanced internal innovation capabilities, executive buy-in for innovation, optimized operating models for innovation, trained innovation teams, new product development (e.g., social innovation fund), better risk management for insurance deals.
ninety_summary: Ninety offers a 123 Framework® for insurance proposition development and market pilot launch, including Stage 1 MVP (1-day) and Stage 2 Design Sprints (2 weeks) using an Experiments WorkbenchTM for lean validation. They provide innovation training through an 'Innovation ABC® journey' and 'Insurance Innovation Bootcamp' to build client capabilities, secure executive buy-in, design operating models, and manage innovation portfolios. Ninety facilitates customer-centric design and offers support for social innovation initiatives.
other_information: Documents from Nov 2019, Feb 2020, Mar 2020. Ninety operates in London, New York, Zurich. Key framework stages: Grasp, Filter, Ideate, Design Sprint, Pilot Prep, Market Pilot, Scale. Uses customer archetypes: Pioneer, Settler, Sheriff. Experian project focuses on 'Risk Score' to help businesses with risk management for insurance. Participation requires various topic leads and customer involvement. Ninety was 'Consultancy of the Year 2019'.

painpoints: Generali is not capturing growth from complex societal risks; startups are better at spotting opportunities but lack Generali's scale; current Generali Ventures setup prevents co-investment, lacks business link, and dedicated FTEs; competitors are actively investing; high pressure due to growing needs, regulation, and saturated markets; lack of in-house VC teams and misalignment with external funds.
desired_solutions: Capture societal risk opportunities leveraging existing distribution; establish new coordination structures and externalized ventures; form cross-cutting coalition with external experts (including Ninety); launch 2 pilots with pipeline; secure exec sponsorship and POC funding; implement Generali Ventures 2.0 (recommended: €100M co-led fund with BUs); utilize VC-as-a-Service for expertise and de-risking.
ninety_summary: Ninety is identified as a potential 'societal risk innovation partner' to add strength to Generali's new cross-cutting coalition coordinating innovation in societal risks.
other_information: Document is a DRAFT FOR DISCUSSION, May 2024. Focus is on social cohesion, income, healthcare, and elder care risks. Opportunity could increase Group results by 5-10% with attractive unit economics. VC market is recovering from a 2023 correction, showing strong Q1-24 performance and positive returns. Generali Ventures (€250M) was established for strategic investments. Competitors like AXA, Munich Re, Allianz, and Zurich are actively investing in InsurTech/CyberTech. VCaaS is a model used by others like AXA Venture Partners.

painpoints: Autopopulation for critical financial and actuals data is failing or incomplete. Inconsistent instructions exist on which sections are editable vs. auto-populated. No actual cost or hour tracking is present, making profitability assessment impossible.
desired_solutions: Ensure reliable autopopulation of all cost, actual hours, and financial metrics. Clarify and standardize instructions for sheet usage. Implement robust mechanisms for tracking actual costs and time spent on projects.
ninety_summary: The Global HDI Gilbert project has a fixed budget of 39900. While planned sales are 39900, the dashboard critically lacks actual cost data, actual hours worked, and therefore real-time profitability metrics. Many sections meant to autopopulate are empty, zero, or show 'Loading...'.
other_information: Client: Global HDI. Project: Global HDI Gilbert. Budget: 39900. Pricing structure: Fixed. Payment notes: 50% upfront, 50% when agreed with client. Planned resources: Nick Reed (84 hrs), Katy Sidebotham (20 hrs). Toby Harvey Scholes (0 hrs). Standard hourly rates for various roles are listed. Dashboard dated 2025-11-12. Resource plan dates: 2023-04-03 to 2023-09-11.

painpoints: Clients struggle to uncover meaningful problems, prioritize ideas, assess viability, develop customer-centric propositions, and avoid common innovation failures like 'no market need' or 'wasting budget/time'. They also face challenges with execution, lack of critical evaluation, prolonged investment in bad ideas, and stakeholder engagement.
desired_solutions: Ninety teaches clients to uncover meaningful problems, prioritize ideas using DVF lenses, adopt customer-centricity, build a common innovation mindset, validate assumptions via experiments, foster creativity through diverse stimuli and psychological safety, use structured prioritization methods (e.g., impact/effort, must-haves), employ the Business Model Canvas for idea assessment, and apply a 'Pass, Fail, Pivot' methodology to save time/money and ensure execution of the right ideas. They also promote iterating on ideas and celebrating failure as a learning opportunity.
ninety_summary: Ninety innovates for the global insurance sector, helping clients become better at innovation. They are multi-award-winning consultants (e.g., Consultancy of the Year 2019, 2020, 2021) based in London, New York, and Zurich. Ninety incubates bold ideas, upskills insurer teams, and creates innovation structures. As a social enterprise, 90% of their distributable profits go to charity, linking client training to global extreme poverty relief.
other_information: This text is from an 'Insurance Innovation Bootcamp: Day 2' agenda, covering topics like creativity, prioritization, Idea 360, and Pass/Fail/Pivot. It references various innovation methodologies and tools such as the Mum test, SCAMPER, Desirability/Feasibility/Viability (DVF), Business Model Canvas, Impact/Effort matrix, Dot voting, and the concept of pivots from 'The Lean Startup'. It includes specific exercises like a 'Climate Levy' case study and a 'Sponsor's swing-o-metre' for decision-making. Contact information for Emily Gardner is provided.

painpoints: Hiscox UK's 2014-2020 strategy is ending, requiring a new strategy through to 2025 for all UK business lines (excluding Lloyds market and reinsurance).
desired_solutions: Sustainably double the business by 2025, achieving GWP >£1bn, Expense Ratio <40%, COR 90%, ROE 15-20%. Outline 3 scenario options for the HIC Board, building on the existing business position.
ninety_summary: Ninety will provide core content expertise and workshop facilitation to help Hiscox UK develop its 2025 strategy. This involves scenario development, market analysis, stress testing, creating Business Model Canvases (BMCs), modelling review, prioritizing initiatives, and defining the 2025 business and operating models with transition states.
other_information: Ninety's team includes a Senior Partner, Delivery Director, Innovation Lead, Innovation Consultant, and optional Strategy research specialist. The engagement will operate as 'one team' collaboratively with Hiscox. Fees are £75-90k indicative net + expenses & tax, on a T&M basis with weekly reconciliations. 90% of Ninety's distributable profits go to social causes.

painpoints: High corporate churn (50% S&P 500 replaced in a decade), 50% workforce reskilling needed by 2025, market pressures (AI, talent war, cost of living), insurance industry under-innovates in 'Great Risks protection gap,' tools alone are insufficient without mindset, cultural change failures due to lack of senior leadership action.
desired_solutions: Ninety's 8 innovation leadership elements (Culture, Leadership, Decisions, Collaboration, Execution, Learning, Risks, Accountability), Innovation Leadership Programme, 123 framework® for rapid insurance idea-to-market in 60 days, customer-centricity, iteration, accountable stage gates, specific leadership sponsorship roles, five key innovation mindsets (experimental, curiosity, creativity, fail fast, customer centricity), support for Innovation Archetypes, leaders must model desired behaviors.
ninety_summary: Award-winning consultancy (2019-2022) and learning provider (2024 Silver) specializing in innovation, particularly insurance. Offers best-in-class innovation training and leadership programs with proprietary frameworks. Driven by a mission to change the world, channeling 90% of distributable profits to poverty alleviation, demonstrated by significant social impact metrics.
other_information: Facilitators include Emily Gardner, Nick Reed, Saray. Program is 'Part 1' of a two-step process. Internal session mindsets are Weekend Self, Time Masters, Digi Mindful, Mutual Support. Uses models like Horizons and Icebergs, advocates Agile methodology. Features AXA Global Healthcare case study. Mentions specific program agendas and external research references (WEF, Innosight).

painpoints: No clear, separate innovation strategy; staff lack time, space, tools, skills, and training for innovation; limited direct customer engagement for innovation; innovation monitoring uses existing change methods; no formal innovation process or support; heavy processes hinder partnerships and idea execution; senior leaders have limited time for innovation; unclear innovation appetite; focus on incremental changes; inconsistent visibility and communication of innovation; low tolerance for failure; lack of clear accountability; no ringfenced funding for bold, early-stage ideas; inconsistent innovation objectives and limited awareness of trends.
desired_solutions: Develop a dedicated innovation strategy and articulate ambition; senior leadership to dedicate time to innovation; increase direct customer engagement and link insights to strategy; improve cross-functional collaboration; introduce an accountability framework and 'fail fast' methodology; regularly communicate innovation activities and successes; embed a culture of empowerment; provide innovation tools; simplify processes for innovation projects and partnerships; introduce a simple, accessible innovation process and resources; create separate funding/rules for early-stage innovation; establish an innovator network; offer innovation skills training; share external innovation insights and link to strategy; clarify long-term partnership strategy.
ninety_summary: Ninety's insurance innovation industry benchmarks (73 insurers) were used for comparison. Ninety's colleagues developed a process, 'identifying a blueprint,' for understanding and developing innovation maturity, codifying 9 key capabilities for effective insurance innovation.
other_information: This is an Innovation Maturity Assessment report for AXA DAC, prepared by Suzanne Brennan from InsTech.ie in March 2023. It outlines findings, recommendations, and industry benchmarks. The methodology included qualitative interviews, a 50-question staff survey, and industry insights. AXA DAC's overall maturity is in line with global benchmarks. The report assesses 7 focus areas: Strategy, Engagement, Monitoring, Empowerment, Process, Learning, and Partnering. AXA DAC scores higher than average on strategy and monitoring due to general business practices, not dedicated innovation approaches, but lower than average on innovation process and learning.

painpoints: Undefined 'How Might We' problem statements; lack of clarity on customer needs for proactivity; need to improve existing innovation capabilities and execution; risk of leading customers in interviews; falling for solutions over problems.
desired_solutions: Implement customer-centric approaches, including a pilot for young single women; introduce curiosity module, thinking pairs, Idea 360, and pass/fail/pivot for ideation; utilize customer interviews and design thinking for idea evaluation (user, business, tech); define innovation, focus on execution, and foster an inclusive, iterative culture; apply Ninety's '123 framework' for rapid idea-to-market; practice non-leading customer interactions, embrace silence, and focus on problems.
ninety_summary: Ninety is an award-winning insurance innovation consultancy (Consultancy of the Year 2019-2022) with 30 staff. It specializes in customer-centric, design thinking methodologies to help insurers innovate and thrive. Ninety offers a '123 framework' for 60-day idea-to-market, emphasizing execution and customer engagement. It also donates 90% of distributable profits to charity, supporting education for the global poor.
other_information: Text is for an 'Insurance Innovation Day' with Irish Life, focusing on improving their innovation capabilities. Discussions include definitions of innovation, corporate longevity, and horizons of innovation. Specific customer toolbox methods are mentioned (e.g., card sorting, 5 whys, ethnographic study). Session mindsets: Weekend Self, Time Masters, Digi Mindful.

painpoints: Manual permission management for sensitive salary data, leading to security risks and inconsistent data visibility across sheets. High risk of breaking formulas due to manual editing of protected cells. Manual template cleanup (deleting instruction boxes) is required. Data inaccuracy due to delayed or manual input of actuals and monthly spend. High administrative burden for project setup and ongoing budget tracking.
desired_solutions: Automated, secure access control for financial data. Centralized system to streamline project budget creation and management. User interface preventing accidental edits of protected/auto-populated cells. Automated integration of actuals (hours, costs, expenses) for real-time accuracy. Elimination of manual template cleanup and complex setup steps. Automated currency conversion.
ninety_summary: Ninety uses a manual, spreadsheet-based budget and project planning system with significant operational painpoints. These include data security risks from manual permission settings, data inconsistency due to linked sheets, high administrative burden, and potential for errors and inaccuracies from manual data entry and template management. The current process lacks automation, leading to delayed and unreliable financial reporting.
other_information: Spreadsheet templates are used for project and budget planning, tracking planned and actual hours, costs, and expenses by role/person. The system integrates with 'Scoro Budget' and references 'Report ARK'. Projects have fixed pricing structures and multiple sponsors. Deals with sensitive salary data and notes currency considerations (e.g., euros).

painpoints: Risk of incorrect sharing permissions for sensitive salary information, potential for users to accidentally amend auto-populated fields, manual and error-prone setup process, reliance on manual data input causing temporary inaccuracies, complexity requiring explicit warnings.
desired_solutions: Automated and secure permission management for sensitive data, user-friendly interface preventing accidental data modification, streamlined and automated project setup, real-time automated data input for actual spend, clear separation or enhanced security for sensitive financial information.

geography: Global (North America, Europe, Latin America, Asia)
painpoints: Missing project success measures, roles & responsibilities, ground rules, and milestones. Untested assumptions threaten to derail new ideas. Need for focused ideation to address future scenarios.
desired_solutions: Establish clear project governance (measures, roles, rules, milestones). Develop 5 concepts with prototypes for construction resilience. Co-create with construction firms. Foster collaborative, virtual teamwork. Implement focused ideation (short/mid/long term). Develop ideas into real products/services using a Business Model Canvas. Assess ideas for desirability, feasibility, viability. Identify and test critical assumptions to de-risk ideas. Create unique IP and differentiated services for Liberty Mutual.
ninety_summary: Innovation experts for the insurance sector. Creates and takes new insurance ideas to market in 60 days using the 123 framework. Builds best practice innovation capability in 12 months. Offers training, op model best practices, market context, innovation delivery, and venture building. Focuses on fast innovations, smarter discipline, and greater self-sufficiency for insurers.
other_information: Project 'Team Onion' for Liberty Mutual Construction Resilience, involving Jupiter Analytics. Workshop series developed 5 ideas: Construction Resiliency Standard, Construction Resilience Score, Transparent Underwriting, Data Exchange, Future Resilience. Workshops followed a structured innovation process: immersion, ideation, business model development, and assumption testing. Focus on ESG and climate readiness.

painpoints: Difficulty accessing session recordings and platform. Unclear coaching booking process. Ineffective problem statement formulation. Global civil unrest and lack of preparedness. High premium spikes post-events. Client focus on risk mitigation over just lower premiums. Disruption to trade from tariffs. Companies not understanding tariff risks. Increased client carbon footprint. Insurance products being too niche. Delays in governmental disaster relief causing human impact. Underinsurance compounding disaster impact. Growing insurance coverage gap. Global food crisis, need for increased production, and climate threats to agriculture. Lack of specific insurance for modern farming techniques like hydroponics.
desired_solutions: Easy access to session recordings and platform. Clear coaching booking process. Use of preferred collaboration tools (e.g., Miro). Customer-led, appropriately scoped problem statements. Improved customer and partner experiences through innovative solutions. Effective ideation techniques and frameworks. Prioritized ideas based on value and feasibility. Live client portals for risk mitigation. Simplified definitions and scores for complex insurance events. Data-driven underwriting for tailored premiums. Insurance for tariff disruption (indemnification, loss of profit, services). Carbon Offset Financial Indemnity (COFI) for excess emissions. Immediate Relief Insurance Solution (IRIS) for displaced people in disasters, using parametric solutions for quick payouts. Specialist insurance for modern farming (e.g., Hydroponic Named Peril insurance).
ninety_summary: Ninety facilitates ideation sessions and problem immersion webinars, providing training, frameworks, and techniques (like How Might We, Problem/Solution/Value) to help teams generate, develop, and prioritize innovative insurance product ideas. Their goal is to improve customer experiences and create solutions for geopolitical and market challenges.
other_information: Session focus: Ideation, learning techniques, generating ideas for an 'idea developers program'. Ninety team members: Emily Gardner (Head of Training), Tim Whittlesea (Learning Experience Designer). Ideation techniques discussed: How Might We, Ideal World, Idea Stretch, Problem/Solution/Value, Nominal Group, Swingometers, Celebrity Personas. Product sprint examples covered: Social Riot (civil unrest), Tariff Protection (trade disputes), COFI (carbon offset), IRIS (disaster relief), Hydro Cover (hydroponic farming). Context is 'Geopolitics Product Sprint, FutureMinds Venture 3'.

painpoints: Companies struggle to stay relevant and innovate (declining S&P 500 tenure). Difficulties in group ideation (production blocking, evaluation apprehension). High startup failure rate (90%) often due to lack of market need, funding, or timing. Wasting time and budget on ineffective innovation.
desired_solutions: Adopt Design Thinking methodology, focusing on customer-centricity. Utilize the 123 framework for rapid innovation (60 days). Apply the 3 lenses of design thinking (desirability, feasibility, viability) for idea evaluation. Implement accountable stage gates and iterative processes. Use a customer toolbox (interviews, card sorting). Clearly articulate problem statements ('How Might We'). Facilitate ideation with psychological safety, quantity, and stimuli. Use Idea 360 and Business Model Canvas for comprehensive assessment.
ninety_summary: Innovation consultancy for the global insurance sector, helping companies innovate and thrive. Awarded 'Consultancy of the Year' (2019-2022) and 'Learning Provider of the Year Silver 2024'. 90% of distributable profits go to charity, supporting the global poor. Offers a '123 framework®' for bringing ideas to market.
other_information: This is an 'Introduction to Design Thinking' presentation. It covers 'Horizons of Innovation' model. Includes 'The Mum Test' principles for customer interviews. Emphasizes 'Fall in love with the problem, not the solution'. Mentions Albert Einstein quote on problem definition. Refers to 'curling' as a top tip for problem statements (context unclear). Uses Oral B vs. Juicero as case studies. Authors: Lídia Sala, Nick Reed.

painpoints: Uncertainty about market innovation bets and trends, difficulty identifying competitive whitespace, doubt about current innovation priorities, lack of objective measurement/benchmarking of innovation effectiveness, internal perception/transparency/accountability issues in innovation, innovation productivity failures (rollercoaster effect).
desired_solutions: Insights on market trends and competitor strategies, review and adjustment of innovation portfolio, diagnostic of innovation effectiveness and maturity, benchmarking against industry peers, practical suggestions to improve innovation culture and practice, access to Ninety's market research reports, expert-guided workshops for strategic planning.

They offer 'Innovation Portfolio Review' for market insights and strategy adjustment, and 'Innovation Healthcheck & Benchmarking' for assessing and improving innovation effectiveness. Known for deep market research, awards, social purpose, and helping insurers innovate and build capability. Research highlights innovation productivity issues, the value of external ideas, and reinsurers being boldest innovators.

painpoints: Pervasive calculation errors (#REF!, #VALUE!, #DIV/0!, #N/A) indicate broken formulas. Manual expense tracking is required outside the calculator. Financial dashboards are not real-time; updated monthly. Extensive manual data entry for roles, rates, and hours is evident. Inconsistent and inaccurate budget remaining/spend tracking.
desired_solutions: Automated, error-free financial calculations including fees, expenses, and profit margins. Real-time financial dashboards and project health metrics. Integrated expense tracking. Streamlined and accurate data input for resources, rates, and hours, leading to reliable budget and spend tracking.
ninety_summary: Ninety can provide an integrated platform to automate project budgeting, financial tracking, and resource management. This would eliminate manual errors, offer real-time visibility into project profitability and budget consumption, and include comprehensive expense management.
other_information: The document is a detailed project financial tracking sheet for 'Tesco Project Peach'. It covers multiple 'Missions' (Alpha, Bravo, Charlie) and 'Sprints', with specific personnel, roles, and hourly rates (cost and sale). It attempts to track weekly and cumulative spend from 2019. Budget calculations for Mission Alpha and Bravo are set at 100k exc VAT.

geography: United States, Canada, United Kingdom, Ireland, Brazil
painpoints: Difficulty balancing inspiring events with practical tools for participants. Need to shift corporate 'Why?' to 'Why not?' mindsets with velocity. Corporate cultures reward risk mitigation, stifling creativity and innovation. Companies lack a widespread innovation mindset among employees. Demand for rapid idea validation and market launch. Need for self-sustaining innovation models and accelerated innovation processes. Desire for deeper cultural change, better creative discipline, and entrepreneurialism. Lack of clear insights, equipped staff, and disciplined innovation.
desired_solutions: Events combining inspiration with practical innovation tools. Equipping teams with innovative thinking for positive change. Rapid prototyping and market pilots (123 Framework, 60 days). Establishing innovation labs and intrapreneurship programs (Lab-in-a-Box, 60-day setup). Implementing cultural change (4-stage methodology). Providing innovation accelerants: training, insights, consumer panels, management tools. Co-creation with clients, involving end-users and SMEs.
ninety_summary: Ninety is an insurance innovation specialist, helping insurers thrive. They offer 60-day Ideas to Market (123 Framework), Innovation Accelerants (Lab-in-a-Box setup), and Deep Culture Tools (4-stage methodology, subscription service). They emphasize co-creation and are a social enterprise, donating 90% of distributable profits to charity.
other_information: Internal financial data for Travelers Project Indigo 2020 (H1/H2 costs, sales, margins for roles like Senior Partner, Delivery Director, Innovation Lead, Consultant). Key personnel: Dan White, Elizabeth Real, Rush, Mark Gravebliss. A 2019 symposium proposal for Travelers HRLDP. Global presence. Numerous industry awards (2016-2018). Significant social impact (e.g., 50k+ educational textbooks, 30k+ clean water access). Clients include Zurich, Direct Line, Allianz, AXA, Co-op, RSA. Dan White contact.

painpoints: Struggle to recruit/retain volunteers. Lack of clear volunteer impact communication. Ineffective volunteer targeting. Poor measurement of recruitment effectiveness. Lack specialist skills/resources to compete. Charities unaware of process issues or available solutions. Limited time for volunteer strategy. Charities feel isolated; poor knowledge sharing. Volunteer drop-off during process. Primary concern is funding/grants.
desired_solutions: Bespoke volunteer recruitment strategies. Customized workshops. Expert guidance for actionable plans. Peer-to-peer matching with experienced charities. Tools to identify KPIs and track volunteer impact. Information services on solutions. Initial needs assessments. Volunteer management training. Follow-up impact measurement and reporting.
ninety_summary: Ninety, as a social enterprise, partners with the Z Zurich Foundation to offer V2: Volunteer reVamp. This service provides tailored volunteer recruitment strategies, workshops, and expert guidance to empower small charities to attract, engage, and retain volunteers, ultimately boosting their community impact.
other_information: 59% of small charities report volunteer recruitment as their main concern. Ninety has won 'Consultancy of the Year' multiple times. The Z Zurich Foundation is a key partner, providing resources and support. Interviewed charities highlighted financial challenges, trainer recruitment issues, volunteer drop-off, and preference for peer mentoring; some found generic workshops too short for complex needs.

painpoints: Static, potentially inefficient presentation of data and deliverables; clients struggle with outdated customer interaction models, high operational costs, and unmet digital customer expectations.
desired_solutions: Adopt electronic/online formats (e.g., Roambi) for improved data presentation and dynamic reporting; implement digital transformation programs for clients, including strategic objectives, guiding principles, and cost-effective digital strategies.
ninety_summary: Ninety delivers Digital Maturity Accelerator services, specializing in Digital Vision & Strategy for clients. They create strategic deliverables, analyze client costs/interactions, and identify digital transformation opportunities. Ninety also manages internal resource costs and seeks to enhance data presentation methods.
other_information: Internal financial model detailing resource utilization, costs, and fees; templates and examples for client deliverables (SMART objectives, guiding principles, CIM summary); an unrelated SmartThings privacy policy.
